skill.name: scientific-brainstorming
skill.description: Creative research ideation and exploration. Use for open-ended brainstorming sessions, exploring interdisciplinary connections, challenging assumptions, or identifying research gaps. Best for early-stage research planning when you do not have specific observations yet. For formulating testable hypotheses from data use hypothesis-generation.

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only markdown documentation (2 files, 518 lines). All 12 static findings are false positives. The scanner matched on benign words like 'algorithm' (appearing in research methods like SCAMPER, TRIZ) and 'explore' (appearing in brainstorming prompts). No executable code, network calls, file operations, or cryptographic implementations exist. Pure documentation skill for research ideation.

content.value_statement: Scientists often struggle to break out of conventional thinking when planning new research. This skill provides structured brainstorming techniques to explore interdisciplinary connections, challenge assumptions, and identify novel research directions through guided ideation.
actual_capabilities: Facilitate structured brainstorming sessions using SCAMPER, TRIZ, and Six Thinking Hats frameworks
Guide researchers through divergent thinking and connection-making phases
Apply cross-domain analogies from biology, physics, chemistry, and engineering to research problems
Challenge assumptions and explore unconventional research directions
Synthesize ideas into concrete research next steps and experimental designs
Adapt techniques when researchers feel stuck or when generated ideas are too safe
limitations: This skill is a ideation tool, not a replacement for literature review or domain expertise
It does not evaluate hypotheses against existing scientific knowledge
Output quality depends on the researcher's ability to articulate their context and constraints
Best for early-stage exploration rather than detailed experimental planning

use_cases.title: Explore thesis directions
use_cases.description: Generate novel research questions and approaches when developing thesis proposals or qualifying exams.

use_cases.title: Identify funding opportunities
use_cases.description: Brainstorm innovative project ideas that differentiate from conventional approaches in grant proposals.

use_cases.title: Bridge field boundaries
use_cases.description: Find unexpected connections between unrelated fields to create novel research collaborations.

prompt_templates.title: Basic exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: I am working on [research area] and want to explore novel directions. Can we brainstorm some unconventional approaches?

prompt_templates.title: Cross-domain connection
prompt_templates.prompt: How might concepts from [field X] apply to my problem in [field Y]? Help me see unexpected connections.

prompt_templates.title: Assumption challenge
prompt_templates.prompt: What are the core assumptions in my field of [research area]? Help me challenge them and explore what if the opposite were true.

prompt_templates.title: Methodology design
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to study [phenomenon]. What experimental designs could I use? Apply [specific framework] to explore options.

output_examples.input: I'm studying antibiotic resistance and want to explore novel approaches. Help me brainstorm.
output: Cross-domain angle: What can we learn from viral evolution about bacterial resistance patterns?
Scale shift: How might resistance work at the community level versus individual bacterial cells?
Constraint reversal: What if antibiotics were designed to increase, not decrease, bacterial cooperation?
Biomimicry approach: How do natural systems like CRISPR handle foreign DNA without resistance?
Potential connection: These ideas suggest studying social bacterial behaviors as resistance drivers

best_practices: Provide detailed context about your research area, including what has already been tried and what constraints you face.
Use specific frameworks (SCAMPER, TRIZ, Six Thinking Hats) when you want targeted exploration techniques.
Follow up on unexpected connections rather than immediately dismissing unconventional ideas.
anti_patterns: Using this skill to replace systematic literature review rather than complement it.
Expecting fully formed research proposals without doing subsequent detailed planning.
Failing to challenge yourself when the skill prompts with provocative questions.

faq.question: How is this different from hypothesis-generation skills?
faq.answer: Brainstorming focuses on generating ideas and exploring possibilities. Hypothesis-generation formulates testable predictions from existing data.

faq.question: Can this help with grant writing?
faq.answer: Yes, use it to develop novel project aims and approaches that differentiate your proposal from conventional approaches.

faq.question: What frameworks does this skill use?
faq.answer: SCAMPER, Six Thinking Hats, Morphological Analysis, TRIZ, Biomimicry, Provocation Technique, and Reverse Assumptions.

faq.question: How long should a brainstorming session last?
faq.answer: Brief sessions work for specific problems. Complex research directions benefit from extended iterative exploration.

faq.question: Can I combine this with other skills?
faq.answer: Yes, follow with hypothesis-generation to turn ideas into testable predictions, or literature-search to validate novelty.

faq.question: What if I feel stuck during a session?
faq.answer: The skill includes adaptive techniques like breaking problems into smaller pieces, changing framing, and using provocation.
